title: 112_hr6561
content:
The "Teachers and First Responders Back to Work Act of 2012" authorizes grants to States for preventing teacher layoffs and creating jobs in public education for the 2012-2014 school years. The Secretary reserves funds for outlying areas, the Secretary of the Interior, and administration. States receive awards based on a set ratio of remaining funds. The Secretary allocates grant awards to States based on population ratios for individuals aged 5 through 17 and total population. If a State does not receive a grant, the Secretary reallocates the funds to other States following the same formula. SEC. 103. STATE APPLICATION. (a) Application.--Within 30 days of this Act's enactment, a State's chief executive must submit an application to the Secretary for a grant under this title, providing necessary information and assurance of maintaining support for education at specified levels for fiscal years 2012 and 2013.
(b) Letter.--If a State chief executive chooses not to receive a grant under this title, they must submit a letter to the Secretary within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Expenditures for a fiscal year equal to or greater than the percentage provided by the State in fiscal year 2011. Chief executive of a State not wanting a grant must submit a letter within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary may waive assurance requirements for a State facing exceptional circumstances or financial decline. SEC. 104. STATE GRANTS. Each State receiving a grant under this title must reserve a portion for State-funded early learning programs and administrative costs. The remaining funds are to be used for awards to local educational agencies for early childhood, elementary, and secondary public education, distributed based on enrollment ratios. The State must allocate grant funds to local educational agencies based on enrollment ratios and funds received under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act. Subgrants must be available to agencies within 100 days of receiving the grant. The State must allocate grant funds to local educational agencies based on enrollment ratios and funds received under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act. Subgrants must be available to agencies within 100 days of receiving the grant. Prohibitions include not using grant funds for rainy-day funds or debt obligations. SEC. 105. Local educational agency subgrants must be used for employee expenses to provide educational services. Funds must be obligated by September 30, 2014. SEC. 106. State-funded early learning programs must use funds for early childhood educators' expenses. Funds must be obligated by September 30, 2014. SEC. 107. Reporting requirements. SEC. 107. REPORTING.

States receiving grants must report on fund usage and job support by September 30 of 2013 and 2014.

SEC. 108. DEFINITIONS.

Defines terms like "State" and "State-funded early learning program."

SEC. 109. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. TITLE II--FIRST RESPONDER STABILIZATION

SEC. 201. PURPOSE.

    This title aims to provide funding to States and localities to prevent layoffs and create jobs for law enforcement officers and firefighters.

SEC. 202. FIREFIGHTER GRANT PROGRAM. The title aims to provide funds to prevent layoffs and create jobs for law enforcement officers and firefighters. The Secretary of Homeland Security will make competitive grants to hire, rehire, and retain firefighters, with an authorization of $1 billion for fiscal years 2012 and 2013. Administrative costs will be covered within this amount. SEC. 203. LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICER GRANT PROGRAM. The Attorney General will provide competitive grants to hire, rehire, and retain law enforcement officers. $4 billion is authorized for fiscal years 2012 and 2013, with a portion reserved for administrative costs.
